EXTRACTED VALUE: Lacks the replayability of its predecessor. [Issue 28, p.118]
There's little reason anyone but a NASCAR fan will buy this game when there's things like GRID, Forza, Gran Tourismo and so forth flying about.
The stuttering on the field obscures what can be a very fun, tense and rewarding game of baseball.
The shooting mechanic is passable, but aiming is excruciatingly slow. The morale mechanic is pretty forgettable.
As wrestling goes, XX is quickly learned and mastered, particularly against the computer. [May 2006, p.83]
With its focus on weapon grabbing over weapon firing, Small Arms' shallow gameplay falls flat.
Uncomplicated, and great for younger gamers and Sega fanboys alike. Instantly playable and with plenty to wave your racket at.
Midway ports the Blitz on the 360, but doesn't feature anything new, apart from visual improvements here and there. Get it only if you didn't already.
With improvements to the A.I. and presentation, Bethesda could be onto something with this simplified "squad-based" style to starship combat.
Aside from the basic RPG elements and decent storylines, Ninety Nine Nights remains a shallow game with little to make it stand out.
It's so colorful that it's likely to lure people of all ages in and keep them hooked. [Issue#29, p.120]
All in all, if put into one word this game is bland.
